channel.title: C# on juri.strumpflohner
channel.description: Recent content in C# on juri.strumpflohner

item.title: 'object' does not contain a definition for 'errors'
item.description: Today I ran into an interesting issues when writing a unit test for an ExceptionFilter which involved inspecting anonymous return types. I basically had the requirement to return a Json object with a predefined structure (for our ASP.

item.title: ASP.net MVC Action Methods: Testing Against Anonymous Return Types
item.description: I don’t use dynamic types regularly, but there are always again situations when they come in quite handy. Here is one example of testing an MVC controller’s return value.

item.title: Programming ASP.net MVC4 by J. Chadwick, T. Snyder and H. Panda
item.description: This is one of the recent books I got from O’Reilly. It is probably the most comprehensive and detailed one I’ve encountered so far regarding ASP.

item.title: Don't Create Your Own Mapper, Let AutoMapper Do The Job!
item.description: Mapping is a common task when integrating different systems with each other. Although it might often seem an unnecessary overhead, it’s highly suggested (even when you communicate within your own systems) as you don’t want to depend on the internal structure of another service.

item.title: Output Caching in ASP.net MVC
item.description: Although nowadays most of us have broadband connections, resource caching is important as loading a resource from your local HD is (by now) still faster than fetching it remotely.

item.title: Lessons Learned: Don't Expose EF Entities to the Client Directly
item.description: When we refactored our main application architecture, moving from an ASP.net WebForms app to a rich client JavaScript application with an ASP.net MVC REST backend, one of our main goals was to keep things as simple as possible.

item.title: ASP.net MVC3: Doesn't Deserialize Nullable Properties from Json
item.description: A couple of days ago I noticed that the Nullable properties of a C# object were not properly deserialized when posting back a Json object to an MVC3 action.

item.title: Don't Fall into the IEnumerable<T> Trap
item.description: Recently I upgraded some code of our company-internal class library and observed a plausible but still tricky problem. See yourself. In a class deep inside the class library ( ;)) there was a method which looked similar to the following:

item.title: Writing IoC Supported Integration Tests using AutoFac
item.description: Using a dependency injection framework can greatly facilitate your code's testability in that you don't have any "glue" code for managing a classes' dependency that needs to be mocked (if even possible) when writing unit tests.

item.title: Some Usability Thoughts for the Weekend...
item.description: A couple of days ago I got the order to write a very simple program that would take a bunch of XML input files with the task to elaborate them in terms of grouping them according to some identifier and then to output the result (grouped per directory) in a more user friendly and readable way.

item.title: Use The "var" Keyword to Have More Maintainable Tests!?
item.description: I have to admit that initially when the "var" keyword has been introduced in C# I was quite precautious in using it. It does reduce code readability, I thought.

item.title: The Similarity of C# and JavaScript Syntax
item.description: I'm currently diving deeply into creating rich JavaScript web applications. You cannot deny that they are now the must have for modern-looking web (2.0) apps.

item.title: How often did you use the Yield keyword??
item.description: If you think about your coding...how often have you used C#'s yield keyword? To be honest I continuously forget to use it myself, too. But it would be so useful in certain scenarious.

item.title: SmellyCode: A Classical Example of Non-Unittestable Code
item.description: I know there might be some degree of repetition in my posts when I speak about unit testing and mocking, but I always again come over similar problems in code I'm reviewing.

item.title: Is It More Readable??
item.description: I was just going over some code and came across some webservice methods having a lot of repetitive conditional statements checking the language - represented by the corresponding two-letter code and send by the client from JavaScript.

item.title: A Test-Driven Dev's Nightmare: Meeting the HttpContext
item.description: My main task for the coming weeks at work is to extend one of our older but highly successful web application with new functionalities. The webapp has become quite complex over the years, as it happens with most applications when they're being extended.

item.title: FriendlyBool Extender What?
item.description: From now and then it happens that I have to databind some entities onto the UI, containing boolean datatypes like "Married" or "Editable" and so on.

item.title: ASP.net: Organize Your Resources the Correct Way!
item.description: ASP.net provides well-known mechanisms for localizing web applications, namely by extracting hard-coded strings into resources files. Localization for Pages and UserControls is fully automated and available from within Visual Studio.

item.title: Smelly Code: Direct Object Instantiation as a Testability Killer
item.description: This Smelly Code post discusses mainly a testability issue without going into further detail on other things like readability which could be improved for sure as well.

item.title: Don't Let Your Test Doubles Fool You
item.description: During unit testing it is common to substitute dependencies with a test double (see Martin Fowler's disambiguation). This is necessary for isolating the tested environment and consequently also the potential source of error in case of a test failure.

item.title: Testing Your SUT Against Exceptions
item.description: When you test your method for exceptions (which is good practice) the usually naive approach - which btw I was following myself till today - is to wrap your method under test with an appropriate try-catch and set a boolean.

item.title: Intercepting WCF Operation Calls with Impersonated Identity
item.description: Take the following scenario. You have a WCF webservice with several operations. The communication runs within a secure SSL channel and uses Kerberos authentication. The webservice application runs with an assigned application pool user, in your .

item.title: Lessons Learned: Make your ListItemCollection Linq Queryable
item.description: I love Linq! In my opinion it is one of the best features that have ever been added to C#, making developers extremely more productive.

item.title: Passing Property Names the "compiler-safe" Way
item.description: A common bad practice which I often find when browsing through code is to see people directly hard-code strings in their source code. I've also proposed some refactorings in some of my previous posts.

item.title: Practical example: Applying the Template Method design pattern
item.description: As I already mentioned in my previous post I'm currently doing domain objects to XSD generated object mapping. Monotonic, exactly, but I'm approaching the end of the work.

item.title: Refactoring for the sake of compactness and reusability
item.description: Currently I'm doing a rather monotonic work, let's call it like this. We basically need to serialize our data to an XML file that has to match a given XSD which has been given to us by our customer.

item.title: HowTo: Launch JavaScript after async postback of UpdatePanel
item.description: Assume the scenario where you want to launch a JavaScript function after your UpdatePanel finished to do its async postback. This turns out to actually be quite simple.

item.title: Add semantic through your code, not through commenting
item.description: Is it good to have a lot of code comments, explaining things s.t. your other team members know what was your intention when writing certain pieces?

item.title: Watch out when cloning objects
item.description: Cloning is never a good thing. I would say in most cases there is a better alternative for reaching your goal, but now and then it happens that you need it.

item.title: NullsafeGet extension method? Simplicity for the cost of readability??
item.description: When programming, there is often the the situation where you have to continuously do the null-check in order to not get exceptions. For instance take the dummy example of a Person object with an according Address object.

item.title: HowTo: Get localized string different from the current culture

item.title: What happens if you think in Java and program C#
item.description: I'm quite jumping between the two languages. In the morning at the university I'm usually programming Java and then in the afternoon at work I'm programming in C#.

item.title: String enumerations in C#
item.description: Enumerations are a very handy programming construct. Especially when you're developing in a larger team, you can prevent a lot of problems and possible bugs by using enum types for properties that can just have certain values.

item.title: HowTo: Make your custom ASP.net server control validatable
item.description: Content validation is a major issue of every application. It is an absolute "must have" to notify the user about invalid data he may have entered.

item.title: Problems with character encoding on cookies
item.description: For preserving the search criteria on some page of our web application we're saving the different settings of the search filters into a cookie. So, when the user comes back next time we can restore the search filter settings that have been used previously.

item.title: HowTo: Detect Assembly dependencies at runtime
item.description: I'm currently developing a small project for myself, where I'm trying to build a small plugin framework (for experimenting purposes). In that environment I just came across the problem of detecting an assemblies dependencies at runtime.

item.description: I don't know why there is none already implemented in the .NET framework. Anyway it wasn't too difficult to write one by myself: /// <summary>

item.title: The ViewState hell: controls loosing their values
item.description: Recently at work I encountered severe problems with the ASP.net viewstate. We have build a very nice framework which we use on our web projects for dynamically adding validation controls to our text-fields or dropdown lists on the UI according to the validity of rules defined in the business logic.

item.title: C# refresher
item.description: Recently I changed work and am now employed at the SIAG, a local informatics company which operates mainly for the public administration sector. Today was my 3rd working day and I'm currently getting some intensive training for being able to join the project team as fast as possible.
